column4: I'm attempting to access the network samba share mounted by fstab (via //samba.egr.msu.edu/web /media/web cifs domain=egr,username=bfortino,password=dtzo7kalai,rw 0 0), unfortunetly, while the share does mount, I only have read only access. No write access.
heh, it was an old password. :D
I think I still use it on a pentium III back home. ;)
you need to specify a umask or uid moun option to allow non root users access
by adding it to the option list you just pasted
it is mounted read/write... but all the files are owned by root with rw---- permissions
why are you trying to chown it?
no... you were told to add the umask option to the mount parameters

linux and windows do not understand each other's permissions systems.... so when you mount an smb share, the kernel just has to make up the file's owner and mode... unless you say otherwise in the mount options, that defaults to root and rwx------
as I said before, to the mount options you pasted earlier
you put a space between two options, the umask, and the rw
yes, each option needs a , between them
